sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This chapter discusses the crucial topic of channel design within the &susemgr; environment and provides an introduction to channel and repository management concepts. This chapter will go over base and child channel relationships, deployment and maintenance of vendor and custom channels, creating repositories, working with GPG keys and content staging. To following along with this chapter it is assumed that &susemgr; is connected to &scc;.

sect1.title: The Importance of Channel Design
sect1.para: The design of your channels influences all other component interaction within &susemgr; and as such, channel design requires careful planning and a concrete understanding of channel terminology. While re-working channels after initial setup is certainly possible, in large environments this will become an increasingly difficult task. Therefore it is important to plan your channel implementation with this consideration in mind, specifically when regarding large production environments.

Channels in &susemgr; are collections of software packages. Like other media types channels contain software packages, patches and updates for client systems. Channels also provide an administrator with strict controls as to which packages may be installed on client systems and make an organizations application life cycle easier to manage.

formalpara.title: Channels and Repositories
formalpara.para: A channel could also be called a package or repository manager. A channel is a collection of RPMs and patch data. Every base channel contains metadata about its packages specific to a product release and architecture. A term that is often confused with channels, is repository. A repository is a storage location from which software packages may be retrieved and installed. A repository can be either local or external. A repository contains a set of packages similar to a channel however a single &susemgr; channel can contain many repositories. A single repository contains package sets. Multiple repositories can be assigned as child channels to a single base channel.

formalpara.title: Base Channels
formalpara.para: Base channels are built on a specific architecture and product, for example a &sle; or RHEL release. A base channel may contain one or more child channels. A traditional client or Salt minion may only be assigned one base channel. If the base channel is a clone (copy) of a SUSE channel it also contains the meta information required to perform a SUSE Manager support pack migration.

formalpara.title: Child channels
formalpara.para: These channels belong to a single base channel and are from the same architecture as the base SLES or RHEL release channel. A registered system may have one or more child channels, but all children must belong to the same base channel.

formalpara.title: Patches
formalpara.para: Patches are a collection of packages which belong together and aid in solving security issues, contain bug fixes or to simply provide an update. The data within a patch is gathered together and termed patches. Regarding SUSE Manager, most actions performed within software channels are executed using these patches.

formalpara.title: Packages
formalpara.para: Packages are RPMs that contain necessary files: configuration, binaries, scripts, as well as pre and post installation scripts.

formalpara.title: Clones
formalpara.para: A clone is a copy of a channel and will include exactly the same information as the original channel. If the original channel receives updates after the clone has been created, these changes need to be updated (or cloned) to the cloned channel. This is a manual process which can be automated with the standard SLES tools. Cloning is especially useful in life-cycle management.
